meta.title: Autonomous AI DMX controller for room-aware, music-reactive light
meta.description: Y-Link turns audio into stable, room-aware, music-reactive lighting with deterministic playback, guardrails, and operator control.

mobile.ctaNote: Limited slots available for early access

footer.tagline: Professional DMX lighting control platform. Engineered for precision, stability, and live performance.

forms.name: Name (optional)
forms.success: Thanks! You're on the list. We'll be in touch when pilot opens.
forms.modalDescription: Express interest, and we'll follow up with pilots and updates.

hero.title: Professional DMX Control.
hero.subtitle: Built for Live Performance.
hero.body: Y-Link is a fully autonomous AI DMX controller that turns audio into room-aware lighting sequences with stable timing. A co-pilot layer for manual cues and triggers complements the AI without overriding it.

features.title: Autonomous Sequences
features.description: Generate lighting cues from audio analysis that understand the room. No manual programming required.

features.title: Precise Timing
features.description: BPM-locked execution with phrase detection. Consistent performance across sessions.

features.title: Co-Pilot Layer
features.description: Manual cues and triggers that complement the AI. Safe adjustments without breaking timing or structure.

howItWorks.title: From Audio to Light
howItWorks.description: Three-stage pipeline designed for reliability and predictability.

steps.title: Audio Analysis
steps.description: Extract tempo, phrase structure, and energy profile from live or imported audio sources.

steps.title: Sequence Generation
steps.description: Generate room-aware cues, transitions, and intensity curves mapped to musical structure.

steps.title: Live Execution
steps.description: Run sequences with co-pilot cues and triggers. Guardrails preserve timing and coherence.

engineering.title: Built for Stability
engineering.description: Measured in pilot deployments across multiple venue types. Optimized for low latency, repeatable output, and operational uptime.
points: Low-latency DMX output with jitter mitigation

runtimeGuarantees.title: Runtime Guarantees

items.title: Deterministic Execution
items.description: Lighting output follows a predictable, frame-consistent execution model. No adaptive heuristics during playback.

items.title: Bounded Latency Path
items.description: Control signals follow a fixed pipeline from scheduler to output, avoiding unbounded buffering or timing drift.

items.title: Explicit Failure States
items.description: Errors surface as known states, not silent degradation. The system fails visibly and recoverably.

items.title: Session-Scoped Control
items.description: All control actions are tied to authenticated sessions with clear ownership and lifecycle.

items.title: Repeatable Show Behavior
items.description: Identical inputs produce identical lighting output across runs, venues, and devices.

runtimeGuarantees.helper: No percentages, no pilot metrics — just the runtime rules the system upholds.

cards.title: Clubs & Venues
cards.description: Consistent shows with minimal staffing requirements

cards.title: Mobile Setups
cards.description: Quick deployment for touring and event productions

cards.title: Small Venues
cards.description: Professional automation without dedicated lighting operator

cta.title: Join the Pilot Program
cta.description: Limited slots available for early access. We're working with select venues to refine the autonomous platform.

metadata.title: About Y-Link
metadata.description: AI-driven DMX controller for music-driven venues. Learn why it exists, who it's for, and how it works.

hero.label: About
hero.title: AI-Powered DMX Controller
hero.subtitle: for Music-Driven Venues
hero.body: Y-Link generates lighting sequences automatically from music with precise timing, guardrails, and a co-pilot layer for manual cues. Built for clubs, small stages, and mobile setups that need predictable shows.

why.title: Why Y-Link
points: Shows that land every time—not random effects.
Fast setup for small venues and mobile rigs.
why.note: The goal is to make solid lighting sequences the standard, not a side project.

steps.title: Audio In
steps.body: Import playlists or use live audio. The system extracts tempo, phrases, and energy.

steps.title: Planned Sequences
steps.body: AI builds cues, transitions, and guardrails that follow the music and your rig.

steps.title: Live with Control
steps.body: Operators use a co-pilot layer for manual cues while the system maintains structure and timing stability.

cta.title: Want to Be Early?
cta.description: Express interest for the pilot. We contact a limited number first.

metadata.title: Technical overview
metadata.description: How Y-Link analyzes audio, plans cues, budgets latency, and delivers safe DMX output.

hero.label: Technical
hero.title: AI-Based DMX with Low Latency, Predictable Playback, and Safety
hero.body: Y-Link analyzes audio, generates room-aware cues, and delivers DMX within strict time requirements. Runtime is tuned for stable latency and a co-pilot layer that keeps the show synchronized.

pipeline.title: Pipeline
items: Audio analysis for tempo, phrases, energy, and changes.
Planner builds cues, transitions, and guardrails per rig.
Output validated against latency budget and safety limits.

safety.title: Safety and Control
safety.body: Operators have locks for intensity, blackout rules, and co-pilot cues. Guardrails prevent random jumps even when adjusting live.

metadata.title: Pilot Program
metadata.description: Validate stability, timing, and usability in real venues with a controlled, time-limited pilot.

hero.title: Pilot Program
hero.subtitle: Controlled Rollout in Real Venues
hero.body: Y-Link is in development. The purpose is to validate stability, timing, and usability in real shows, with structured technical and operational feedback. This is a controlled pilot, not an open beta giveaway.

whatIs.title: What the Pilot Is
items: Validate stability, timing, and operation in real venue environments.
Collect structured technical and operational feedback.
Controlled pilot with few partners - not an open beta.
Time-limited period: approximately 4-8 weeks.
Y1 hardware loaned out, Y-Link property, returned after pilot. Hardware and software are in active development.

whatNot.title: What It Is Not
items: Not a finished commercial product.
Not a free hardware giveaway.
Not full production coverage - focus is on pilot verification.

partnersGet.title: What Pilot Partners Get
items: Temporary loan of Y1 hardware (pilot/pre-production unit)
Full access to Y-Link Studio during pilot period
Music-reactive AI lighting with deterministic playback
Setup assistance and direct dialogue with the team
Ongoing software updates throughout the pilot

expectations.title: What We Expect
items: Use in real shows or events
Feedback on stability, timing, and show quality
Willingness for short feedback sessions
Optional: consent for anonymous pilot case study

cta.title: Ready to Become a Pilot Partner?
cta.body: One point of contact, quick feedback, and updates throughout the pilot period.

metadata.title: FAQ
metadata.description: Common questions about Y-Link, the AI DMX controller, the pilot program, and email preferences.

hero.label: Support
hero.title: Frequently Asked Questions
hero.body: Get clarity on what's automated, how operators maintain control, and how to sign up or unsubscribe.

items.a: The controller analyzes audio for tempo, phrases, energy, and room context. It builds cues, transitions, and guardrails that follow the track without manual programming.

items.q: Can operators still control the rig?
items.a: Yes. Operators use a co-pilot layer for manual cues and triggers, approve looks, lock intensity, and rehearse sections. The co-pilot complements the AI without overriding it, keeping playback predictable.
Each step is budgeted, and playback is validated before output. Runtime is tuned for low jitter in clubs and small venues.

items.q: Which fixtures and universes are supported?
items.a: We target common DMX universes with profiles for clubs and small venues. Universe planning and saturation checks run before playback.

items.q: How do I join the pilot or pre-order?
items.a: Use the form on the homepage or pilot page. Y-Link is in development, and the pilot is time-limited (approx. 4-8 weeks), with Y1 hardware loaned and returned afterward. We take in a small, curated group to test stability, timing, and UX.

items.q: How do I unsubscribe from emails?
items.a: Each email has an unsubscribe link. You can also visit /unsubscribe?token=<your-token> to remove your address immediately.

metadata.title: Privacy
metadata.description: How Y-Link handles contact data for pilots, early interest, and updates.

body: We collect name (optional), email, and selected interest so we can send Y-Link updates, coordinate pilot access, or follow up on early interest.
Data is stored securely in Supabase. Emails include an unsubscribe link that stops communication immediately. We do not sell or share contact information with third parties.
To delete data, email hello@y-link.no and we will remove the record.

metadata.title: Pilot Access
metadata.description: Invite-only sign-in for approved pilot participants.

hero.label: Pilot Access
hero.title: Sign in with invite
hero.body: Only approved pilots. Requires email registered with us and a valid invitation code. No password or account needed.

metadata.title: Unsubscribe
metadata.description: Unsubscribe from Y-Link updates.

messages.error: Something went wrong. Please try again later.
messages.expired: The link has expired or has already been used.
messages.success: You have been unsubscribed from Y-Link emails.

cta.question: Unsubscribed by mistake?
cta.link: Sign up again on the homepage

metadata.title: AI DMX Controller
metadata.description: Y-Link is a fully autonomous AI DMX controller in development, converting audio into room-aware, music-driven lighting with low latency and guardrails.

hero.label: Platform
hero.title: AI DMX Controller
hero.subtitle: for Music-Reactive Lighting
hero.body: Y-Link is a fully autonomous AI DMX controller in development that converts audio to room-aware lighting sequences that follow tempo, phrasing, and energy. Low latency, guardrails, and a co-pilot layer ensure your show is predictable, not random.

summary.title: Product Summary
points: Transforms audio into deterministic DMX cues with stable timing.
Co-pilot layer for manual cues and safe live adjustments.
Designed for clubs, small venues, and mobile rigs.

steps.title: Audio Input
steps.body: Upload music or use live audio. The system captures tempo, phrases, and energy.

steps.title: Planning
steps.body: AI plans room-aware cues, transitions, and safety limits tailored to your rig.

steps.title: Deterministic Playback
steps.body: Signals are timed and monitored before output. Co-pilot cues and triggers stay inside guardrails.

who.title: Who It's For
items: Clubs and bars wanting music-reactive lighting without manual programming.
Small stages and installations with minimal staffing but timing requirements.
Mobile rigs needing fast load-ins and predictable playback.
Operators wanting guardrails and a co-pilot layer for manual cues.

setup.title: Setup Requirements
items: Audio upload or live feed
Fixture list and universes for planning and safety
Network for updates and remote monitoring
Operator interface (desktop or iPad)
setup.note: Timing and saturation validated before show so rehearsal matches live.

cta.title: Next Steps
cta.body: Need music-reactive lighting with predictable timing? Join the pilot, and we'll document latency in your rig and fine-tune guardrails.

metadata.description: See where Y-Link fits: clubs, small venues, and teams that want automation without losing control.

hero.label: Applications
hero.title: Where Y-Link Fits Best
hero.body: Music-reactive automation, low latency, and operator override make Y-Link suitable where staffing is lean and timing is critical.

cards.title: Music-Reactive DMX for Clubs

cards.title: Automated DMX for Small Venues
cards.detail: Less manual programming, same expression night after night.

metadata.title: Music-Reactive DMX Lighting for Clubs
metadata.description: Keep club lighting synced to every track with Y-Link.

hero.title: Music-Reactive DMX Lighting for Clubs
hero.body: Deliver a tight, music-driven show without programming each track by hand. Y-Link analyzes audio and controls DMX with low latency, so the operator can follow the room instead of the console.

features.title: Audio-Driven Cues
features.body: Upload playlists or use a live mix. The controller follows tempo, phrasing, and energy.

features.title: Predictable Timing
features.body: Latency budget is monitored. No surprises when the room fills and load changes.

features.title: Guardrails for Operators
features.body: Intensity limits, blackout rules, and approvals keep the rig safe.

features.title: Quick Switches
features.body: Repertoire can be rehearsed, cues locked, and playlists swapped quickly between DJs.

musicReactive.stepsTitle: How to Set Up in a Club
steps: Share fixture list, universe setup, and room constraints.
Upload a starter playlist or connect live audio.
Run preflight for timing, saturation, and safety limits.
Rehearse sections, lock important looks, and set operator override.
Go live with monitoring; adjust intensity or looks as needed.

cta.title: Next Steps

cta.secondary: Read the latency and jitter guide

metadata.title: DMX Guides
metadata.description: Guides that build DMX fundamentals and support AI-driven, music-reactive control.

hero.label: Resources
hero.title: DMX Guides for AI-Controlled Lighting
hero.body: Build a solid foundation so AI-based DMX automation lands safely in your space. Each guide links back to the main AI DMX controller page for context.

metadata.title: DMX Basics
metadata.description: Understand DMX signals, universes, and fixtures as a foundation for AI-driven light.

hero.label: Guide
hero.title: DMX Basics
hero.body: A brief introduction to DMX so your fixture planning aligns with AI-generated cues from the Y-Link controller.

signal.title: Signal and Universe
signal.body: DMX512 sends 512 channel values per universe. Each fixture uses channels based on the selected mode. Predictable automation requires clear mapping of fixtures to universes and overview of channel usage.
items: Map all fixtures with address and channel footprint.
Keep universes under safe utilization to avoid timing issues.
Document cabling, splitters, and nodes.

modes.title: Fixture Modes
modes.body: Choose modes that balance control against channel count. Higher modes give more control but use more channels. The AI planner needs correct patch to avoid saturation.

metadata.title: Fixture Addressing
metadata.description: Learn to address fixtures correctly for stable AI-driven light sequences.

hero.label: Guide
hero.title: Fixture Addressing
hero.body: Correct addressing ensures AI-planned cues hit the right channel every time.

plan.title: Plan Your Patch
items: Keep an updated patch list with start address and mode.
Group similar fixtures for tidy universes.
Avoid overlap by reserving buffer zones where rigs change often.

validate.title: Validate Against Controller
validate.body: Y-Link checks the patch before show. Mismatches between patch and actual rig can cause wrong mapping and timing drift.

metadata.title: DMX Universes and Scaling
metadata.description: How to plan universes and scale the rig without losing timing.

hero.label: Guide
hero.title: DMX Universes and Scaling
hero.body: Good universe planning ensures AI-generated signals maintain timing even as the rig grows.

distribute.title: Distribute the Load
items: Keep universes under safe utilization; avoid pushing to 512 on busy shows.
Distribute power consumption and cable routes to minimize noise and loss.
Plan reserved universes for temporary fixtures.

scaling.title: Scaling
scaling.body: When adding universes, ensure the controller and nodes support synchronous clock and latency monitoring. Y-Link enforces timing per universe, but needs correct topology.

metadata.title: Latency and Jitter in DMX
metadata.description: How to measure and control latency and jitter in an AI-controlled DMX rig.

hero.label: Guide
hero.title: Latency and Jitter in DMX
hero.body: Timing is the core value in music-reactive lighting. Here's how we measure, budget, and monitor latency and jitter.

measurement.title: Measurement
items: Measure end-to-end latency with known test audio and sensor on light.
Look for jitter (variation) between cues and output.
Log under full load, not just in an empty room.

control.title: Control
control.body: Y-Link budgets each step and monitors drift. If deviations are detected, output is tightened or the operator is notified. Keep network and nodes stable for best results.

metadata.title: DMX Best Practices
metadata.description: Practical tips for stable DMX rigs when AI controls the light sequences.

hero.label: Guide
hero.title: DMX Best Practices
hero.body: Routines that keep timing stable and guardrails effective when AI controls the lights.

before.title: Before Show
items: Verify patch and universes against the rig.
Run preflight on latency, jitter, and saturation.
Define operator override and emergency procedures.

during.title: During Show
items: Keep network and nodes under observation.
Use guardrails instead of manual jumps when possible.
Log deviations for later adjustment.

metadata.title: DMX Troubleshooting
metadata.description: Common errors in DMX rigs and how to solve them when AI drives the light sequences.

hero.label: Guide
hero.title: DMX Troubleshooting
hero.body: Typical problems and quick actions to keep the show stable.

errors.title: Common Errors
items: Signal drops: check cables, termination, and nodes.
Wrong mapping: verify patch and addressing.
Timing glitches: look for network load and node health.

checklist.title: Quick Checklist
items: Confirm universe and address assignment.
Check that guardrails and safety limits are active.
Restart nodes on fault condition, log the event.

metadata.title: Blog
metadata.description: Updates, field notes, and product insights from the Y-Link team.

hero.label: Resources
hero.title: Y-Link Blog
hero.body: Technical notes, product updates, and lessons from building reliable, music-reactive lighting systems.

metadata.title: Alternatives to AI DMX Controller
metadata.description: Compare Y-Link with other music-reactive and AI-driven lighting solutions.

hero.label: Comparison
hero.title: Alternatives to Y-Link
hero.body: Use this overview to evaluate whether you need AI automation with guardrails, or a more traditional console with audio triggers.

options.name: Y-Link
options.focus: AI-driven, music-reactive DMX with low latency and operator guardrails.
options.bestFor: Clubs, small venues, and mobile rigs with minimal staffing.

options.name: MaestroDMX
options.focus: Audio analysis and lighting automation for DJ sets.
options.bestFor: DJ-focused setups where music cues drive the scenes.

options.name: Lightkey (sound active)
options.focus: Manual programming + audio triggers on macOS.
options.bestFor: Operators wanting deep manual control with simple audio response.

options.name: Onyx + add-on modules
options.focus: Full console with optional audio triggers.
options.bestFor: Larger rigs with dedicated LDs who still want to follow music.

consider.title: What to Consider
items: Latency and jitter under full load.
How clear guardrails are for the operator.
How quickly rig data can be patched and validated.
Ability to override live without automation breaking down.

metadata.title: Y-Link vs MaestroDMX
metadata.description: Brief comparison of Y-Link and MaestroDMX for music-reactive lighting.

hero.label: Comparison
hero.title: Y-Link vs MaestroDMX
hero.body: Two different approaches to music-reactive lighting. Here's how they differ.

comparison.label: Focus
comparison.ylink: AI-planned light sequences with guardrails and low latency.
comparison.maestro: Audio analysis and automation for DJ sets.

comparison.label: Operator Control
comparison.ylink: Approvals, locks, and override without losing structure.
comparison.maestro: DJ-oriented workflow with more manual control.

comparison.label: Best For
comparison.ylink: Clubs/small venues with minimal staffing needing predictability.
comparison.maestro: DJ-focused rooms wanting to trigger lights directly from music.

metadata.title: DMX Tools
metadata.description: Fast, practical DMX tools for patching and addressing.

hero.label: Tools
hero.title: DMX Tools for Fast Patching
hero.body: Practical utilities for lighting techs and operators. Start with the DMX Patch Sheet Generator.

cards.title: DMX Address + Universe Planner
cards.description: Plan addresses on a live 512-channel grid and catch overlaps before patching.

cards.title: DMX Patch Sheet Generator
cards.description: Auto-pack fixtures across universes and export clean patch sheets.

cards.title: DMX Color Picker & RGB to DMX
cards.description: Convert HEX or RGB to DMX values for RGB, RGBW, RGBWA, and RGBWW/CW fixtures.

cards.title: DMX Address Capacity Calculator
cards.description: See how many fixtures fit per universe and how many universes you need.

metadata.title: DMX Color Picker & RGB to DMX Converter
metadata.description: DMX color picker and HEX to DMX converter. Get RGB, RGBW, RGBWA, and RGBWW/CW DMX values with optional CCT channel calculation.

intro.title: Convert color to DMX values fast
intro.body: Use HEX, RGB sliders, or CCT to get clean DMX channel values for common fixture types. Optimized whites keep pastel and neutral tones accurate without changing saturated colors.

howTo.title: How to use the DMX color picker
steps: Enter a HEX color or dial in RGB with the sliders.
Choose your fixture type (RGB, RGBW, RGBWA, or RGBWW/CW).
Optional: add a CCT value for white channel fixtures or RGB mixing.
Copy the 8-bit or 16-bit channel values.

items.question: Does this work for RGBW and RGBWW/CW fixtures?
items.answer: Yes. The tool can extract neutral whites for RGBW and split warm/cool white channels when your fixture supports WW/CW.

items.question: Why does my white look pinkish?
items.answer: Pure RGB mixes can tint white. The Optimize whites option uses a white LED for near-neutral and pastel colors while preserving saturated hues.

items.question: Do you output 16-bit values?
items.answer: Yes. You get both 8-bit and 16-bit values plus coarse and fine channels for fixtures that use fine control.

items.question: Can I use CCT for RGB fixtures?
items.answer: Yes. If your fixture does not have WW/CW channels, the tool blends RGB values to approximate the chosen color temperature.

sections.title: White channel guardrails
sections.body: White is only used for near-neutral or pastel colors. Saturated hues stay pure RGB so your intent is preserved.

sections.title: Warm vs cool white
sections.body: For RGBWW/CW fixtures, warm and cool whites are blended based on the target color temperature.

sections.title: Coarse vs fine channels
sections.body: Use coarse-only for 8-bit control, or include fine channels when your fixture supports 16-bit precision.

sections.title: Amber handling
sections.body: Amber is used conservatively for warm tones.

inputs.title: Color input
inputs.colorWheelHelp: Drag to set color, then fine-tune the output format.
inputs.cctHelp: Uses WW/CW if available, otherwise blends RGB to match the CCT.
inputs.cctIntensityHelp: Sets the output level for CCT mode.

options.title: Fixture settings
options.optimizeWhitesHelp: Uses white LEDs for neutral and pastel colors. Saturated hues are unaffected.
options.limitWhiteHelp: Caps white output to avoid harsh LEDs on cheaper fixtures.

notices.cctOverride: CCT mode active: RGB channels set to 0, WW/CW only.
notices.cctRgbBlend: CCT mode active: RGB channels blended to match the Kelvin value.

cta.title: Need more DMX utilities?
cta.body: Browse the full tools list for patching, capacity, and planning.

metadata.title: DMX Patch Sheet Generator
metadata.description: Auto-pack fixtures across DMX universes and export clean patch sheets.

intro.title: What a DMX patch sheet is
intro.body: A patch sheet lists every fixture with its universe, start address, and channel footprint. It keeps operators, techs, and consoles aligned.
intro.overlapsBody: Overlaps usually come from manual counting, fixture mode changes, or last-minute adds. This tool packs fixtures sequentially so every channel is unique.
audienceItems: Lighting techs building patches on site
Operators who need quick, reliable addressing
Rental teams prepping rigs before load-in

sections.title: How DMX universes work
sections.body: Each universe holds 512 channels. Fixtures consume a block of channels based on their mode.

sections.title: Common addressing mistakes
items: Reusing an address after changing a fixture mode.
Forgetting to move to the next universe when a fixture no longer fits.
Mixing 1-based and 0-based address labeling on paper vs console.

sections.title: When to leave gaps
sections.body: Leave space when fixtures get swapped often or when you expect mode changes. Otherwise, pack tightly to keep wiring simple.

sections.title: 8-bit vs 16-bit channels
sections.body: 16-bit parameters consume two DMX channels. Always confirm the channel count for the selected mode before patching.

sections.title: Not sure how many fixtures fit?
sections.body: Use the capacity calculator to estimate fixtures per universe before you build a full patch sheet.

howTo.title: How to generate a DMX patch sheet
steps: Set your starting universe and address.
Add your fixtures and channel counts.
Enter quantities or duplicate rows.
Generate the patch sheet.
Export or print your results.

items.question: Can I use this DMX patch sheet with GrandMA / Chamsys / ETC?
items.answer: Yes. The generated patch sheet uses standard universe + start address notation that works with all major consoles. Exported CSV files can be imported or referenced directly.

items.question: How many fixtures fit in one DMX universe?
items.answer: That depends on channel count per fixture. A universe has 512 channels. For example, 13-channel fixtures allow up to 39 fixtures per universe (39 x 13 = 507).

items.question: Does this tool support 16-bit fixtures?
items.answer: Yes. Just enter the total channel count for the fixture mode. 16-bit parameters already count as two channels.

items.question: Does this tool prevent overlapping addresses?
items.answer: Yes. Fixtures are packed sequentially and never share channels. If a fixture does not fit, the tool automatically moves to the next universe.

limitations.title: Tool limitations
limitations.intro: This tool focuses on fast, reliable addressing. It does not:
items: Load fixture libraries or profiles.
Optimize patching for console-specific workflows.
Save patches between sessions (yet).
limitations.outro: For advanced workflows, see our upcoming tools or guides.

addressNote.title: Address notation note
addressNote.body: Some consoles display addresses as 1.001, others as U1 / 001. This tool uses industry-standard 1-based addressing. Always confirm console display preferences when entering addresses.

proCta.title: Working on larger rigs?
proCta.body: If you regularly patch complex shows, multi-universe rigs, or time-coded setups, Y-Link is built for precision playback and deterministic control.

settings.title: Global settings
settings.subtitle: Define where packing starts and how many channels each universe allows.

fixtures.title: Fixture table
fixtures.subtitle: Add fixture rows, then duplicate them when you need similar fixtures.
fixtures.name: Fixture name

output.title: Patch sheet output
output.subtitle: One row per physical fixture. Addresses are 3-digit padded.
output.empty: Generate the patch sheet to see output.
output.largeRigWarning: Heads up: this patch uses {count} universes.

print.patchSubtitle: Generated patch list with universe and address per fixture.
print.labelsSubtitle: A4 grid labels for quick fixture tagging.
print.popupBlocked: Popup blocked. Allow popups for this site to print or export PDF.

validation.startAddressTooHigh: Starting address is above the available channels per universe.

warnings.startAddressTooHigh: Starting address is above the available channels. Reset to 1.
warnings.fixtureTooLarge: {name} exceeds {channels} channels per universe. Each unit is placed at the next universe.

cta.title: Explore more tools
cta.body: Looking for another DMX utility? Browse the full tools list.

metadata.title: DMX Address Capacity Calculator
metadata.description: Calculate how many fixtures fit in a DMX universe and how many universes you need.

intro.title: How many fixtures fit in a universe?
intro.body: This calculator shows the maximum fixtures per universe, leftover channels, and how many universes you need based on fixture count.

howTo.title: How to use this calculator
steps: Enter channels per fixture.
Optional: add the fixture count you plan to run.
Confirm channels per universe (default is 512).
Review fixtures per universe, leftover channels, and universes required.

items.question: How many 13-channel fixtures fit in one universe?
items.answer: 39 fixtures fit in a 512-channel universe, leaving 5 channels free.

items.question: Does this work for 16-bit fixtures?
items.answer: Yes. Enter the total channel count for the fixture mode. 16-bit parameters already count as two channels.

items.question: What if my fixture count exceeds one universe?
items.answer: The calculator shows how many universes you need and warns when the count will not fit in a single universe.

sections.title: Universe limits are fixed
sections.body: A universe has 512 channels. Fixture mode determines how many channels each unit uses.

sections.title: Mode changes affect capacity
sections.body: Switching from 8-bit to 16-bit control doubles channel usage and reduces fixtures per universe.

sections.title: When to leave headroom
sections.body: Leave spare channels if you expect mode changes, add-on fixtures, or future expansion.

outputs.title: Results
outputs.warning: Warning: this fixture count will not fit in a single universe.
outputs.notPossible: This fixture mode exceeds the available channels per universe.

cta.title: Ready to generate a full patch sheet?

metadata.title: DMX Address + Universe Planner
metadata.description: Plan DMX addresses on a live 512-channel grid with overlap detection and universe summary.

intro.title: Plan addresses visually
intro.body: Place fixtures on a 512-channel grid, see overlaps instantly, and keep universes clean.

howTo.title: How to use the address planner
steps: Add fixtures with name, channel count, and type.
Select a fixture and click a channel to place it.
Use Next free address to auto-pack the grid.
Review overlaps and the universe summary.

fixtures.title: Fixtures
fixtures.subtitle: Define fixtures before placing them on the grid.
fixtures.name: Name

grid.title: Universe {universe} grid
grid.subtitle: Select a fixture, then click a channel to place it.

warnings.noSpace: No space available for this fixture.
warnings.noFixturesPlaced: Place at least one fixture before sending.

status.selectFixture: Select a fixture to place it.
status.noFixtures: Add a fixture to start planning.

items.question: Does this prevent overlapping addresses?
items.answer: Overlaps are highlighted on the grid and listed below so you can fix them immediately.

items.question: What if a fixture does not fit in the universe?
items.answer: You'll see a warning if the placement exceeds the 512-channel limit.

sections.title: Universe size
sections.body: Each universe holds 512 channels. This grid visualizes one universe at a time.

sections.title: Packing strategy
sections.body: Use Next free address to find the first contiguous space for the selected fixture.

cta.title: Need a printable patch sheet?
cta.body: Export a clean patch sheet once your plan is locked.

metadata.title: Y-Link Studio Download
metadata.description: Download Y-Link Studio if your pilot access is active.

access.label: Download
access.title: Access Not Active
access.body: Your access is not active or has expired. Contact Y-Link if you believe this is an error.

active.label: Download
active.title: Y-Link Studio
active.body: Access verified. Download is delivered via protected endpoint. No direct links are exposed.
